Analysis of Linked Files: A Missing Data Perspective

GauriÂ Kamatlabel=e1]gaurik1.edu@gmail.com\orcid0000-0001-9338-0820 [ â€ƒâ€ƒ RoeeÂ Gutmanlabel=e2]rgutman@stat.brown.edu [ Gauri Kamat is PhD candidate in Biostatistics, Brown Universitypresep=Â ]e1. Roee Gutman is Associate Professor of Biostatistics, Brown Universitypresep=Â ]e2.
Abstract

In many applications, researchers seek to identify overlapping entities across multiple data files. Record linkage algorithms facilitate this task, in the absence of unique identifiers. As these algorithms rely on semi-identifying information, they may miss records that represent the same entity, or incorrectly link records that do not represent the same entity. Analysis of linked files commonly ignores such linkage errors, resulting in biased, or overly precise estimates of the associations of interest. We view record linkage as a missing data problem, and delineate the linkage mechanisms that underpin analysis methods with linked files. Following the missing data literature, we group these methods under three categories: likelihood and Bayesian methods, imputation methods, and weighting methods. We summarize the assumptions and limitations of the methods, and evaluate their performance in a wide range of simulation scenarios.

1 Introduction

In many healthcare and social science applications, information about entities is dispersed across multiple data files. To investigate the associations of interest, researchers seek to link records representing the same entity across these files. When unique identifiers, like social security numbers, are available, linking records is a relatively straightforward task. However, privacy regulations often limit access to such identifiers. In these situations, researchers rely on semi-identifying linking variables, such as names and addresses. Record linkage (data matching or entity resolution) is a statistical technique that identifies records representing the same entity across multiple files, in the absence of unique identifiers. Record linkage techniques have found applications in epidemiology and healthcare (Stern,, 1986; Brenner etÂ al.,, 1997; Golden and Mirel,, 2021), official statistics (Winkler and Thibaudeau,, 1991; Dasylva etÂ al.,, 2014), economics (Meyer and Mittag,, 2019, 2021), and studies of human rights violations (Sadinle,, 2014).

Record linkage methods can be broadly categorized as being deterministic or probabilistic. Deterministic linkage methods are based on non-random similarity functions defined on the linking variables. These methods can link records with high accuracy, when the linking variables are informative and accurately reported (Gomatam etÂ al.,, 2002). However, when these variables are subject to variations in spelling, data entry errors, or incompleteness, deterministic methods may perform inadequately (Campbell etÂ al.,, 2008; Newman etÂ al.,, 2009; Zhu etÂ al.,, 2015). Probabilistic linkage is based on the likelihood that a given pair of records represents the same entity. This likelihood can be computed in several ways, such as using mixture models (Fellegi and Sunter,, 1969), microclustering models (Zanella etÂ al.,, 2016), or classification algorithms (Cochinwala etÂ al.,, 2001).

A widely-used approach to probabilistic record linkage is the mixture model proposed by Fellegi and Sunter, (1969). For computational convenience, this model relies on several tacit independence assumptions. In addition, identification of linked records is based on subjective thresholds (Winkler,, 2014; Binette and Steorts,, 2022). These features have often been criticized (Tancredi and Liseo,, 2011), motivating the development of parametric Bayesian approaches for probabilistic linkage (Tancredi and Liseo,, 2011; Gutman etÂ al.,, 2013; Steorts etÂ al.,, 2016; Sadinle,, 2017).

Probabilistic record linkage has also been viewed as a prediction problem (Lee etÂ al.,, 2022). In this approach, classification algorithms, like decision trees, are used to determine if a pair of records represents the same entity (Cochinwala etÂ al.,, 2001; Bilenko and Mooney,, 2003). Such algorithms rely on the availability of training data, i.e., a known set of links, to estimate parameters in the classification algorithm. These estimates are then used to predict the unknown linkage status of record pairs. In the absence of training data, unsupervised classification algorithms, such as kğ‘˜k-means clustering, can be employed to link records (Liu etÂ al.,, 2003; Gu and Baxter,, 2006; Christen,, 2007; Christen, 2008a, ; Christen, 2008b, ). The performance of both supervised and unsupervised classification algorithms can depend on the distance functions used to compare the records (Asher etÂ al.,, 2020). When reliable training data is available, supervised algorithms can outperform unsupervised algorithms in terms of linkage accuracy (Elfeky etÂ al.,, 2003; Liu etÂ al.,, 2003).

In this article, we exclusively focus on probabilistic record linkage when no training data is available. We also do not focus on predictive classification approaches to probabilistic linking, which have been comprehensively reviewed in Binette and Steorts, (2022).

When the linking variables contain limited information, probabilistic linking algorithms may miss links between records representing the same entity, or falsely link records representing different entities. When analyzing linked files, such errors can lead to substantial biases and a loss in efficiency (Neter etÂ al.,, 1965). In this article, we review statistical methods to propagate the uncertainty stemming from linkage errors into the post-linkage analysis. We do so by formulating record linkage within a missing data framework (Rubin,, 1976), and formalizing linkage mechanisms that underlie inferential methods with linked files. In addition, we characterize and compare the performance of selected linkage and inference methods under a wide variety of scenarios.

This article is organized as follows. The remainder of Section 1 provides notation and background on probabilistic record linkage. Sections 2 and 3 identify and discuss inferential methods with linked files. Section 4 describes simulations to compare the performance of selected methods from Sections 2 and 3. Section 5 concludes with a discussion.

1.1.2 The Fellegi-Sunter model

A commonly used model to estimate the linkage structure is that of Fellegi and Sunter, (1969) (FS), which builds on the work of Newcombe etÂ al., (1959). The probabilities mâ€‹(Î³iâ€‹j)ğ‘šsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘—m(\gamma_{ij}) and uâ€‹(Î³iâ€‹j)ğ‘¢subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘—u(\gamma_{ij}) are unknown, and are estimated using the Expectation-Maximization (EM) algorithm (Dempster etÂ al.,, 1977; Belin and Rubin,, 1995). Let m^â€‹(Î³iâ€‹j)^ğ‘šsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘—\hat{m}(\gamma_{ij}) and u^â€‹(Î³iâ€‹j)^ğ‘¢subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘—\hat{u}(\gamma_{ij}) be the estimates of mâ€‹(Î³iâ€‹j)ğ‘šsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘—m(\gamma_{ij}) and uâ€‹(Î³iâ€‹j)ğ‘¢subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘—u(\gamma_{ij}), respectively. The FS model assigns an estimated weight to record pair (i,j)ğ‘–ğ‘—(i,j) as w^iâ€‹j=logÂ â€‹m^â€‹(Î³iâ€‹j)u^â€‹(Î³iâ€‹j)subscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘—logÂ ^ğ‘šsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘—^ğ‘¢subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘—\hat{w}_{ij}=\text{log }\frac{\hat{m}(\gamma_{ij})}{\hat{u}(\gamma_{ij})}.

Each record pair is classified as a link, non-link, or a possible link, by comparing w^iâ€‹jsubscript^ğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘—\hat{w}_{ij} to two fixed thresholds (Tepping,, 1968; Binette and Steorts,, 2022). Choosing optimal thresholds is a subjective process, based on manual review of record pairs (Dusetzina etÂ al.,, 2014), or on the evaluation of linkage quality measures at different threshold values (Christen and Goiser,, 2005, 2007).

The original FS model classifies the linkage status of each record pair independently, often resulting in many-to-one links. Jaro, (1989) addressed this, by introducing a linear sum optimization as a precursor to the FS model.

Multiple extensions to the FS model have been proposed. These include incorporating information from clerical reviews (Larsen and Rubin,, 2001), modeling the dependence between linking variables (Winkler,, 1993; SchÃ¼rle,, 2005; Xu etÂ al.,, 2019), handling continuous-valued linking variables (Vo etÂ al.,, 2023), handling missing data (Li etÂ al.,, 2022; Sadinle,, 2017), testing the conditional independence assumption (Xu etÂ al.,, 2022), improved scalability (Enamorado etÂ al.,, 2019), and extensions to multi-file linkage (Sadinle and Fienberg,, 2013; Aleshin-Guendel and Sadinle,, 2022; Taylor etÂ al.,, 2024).

1.1.3 Linkage errors

Given that probabilistic linkage relies on semi-identifying information, the estimated ğš«ğš«\mathbf{\Delta} is seldom error-free. In particular, a linked file may contain two kinds of linkage errors: (i) false links between records representing different entities; and (ii) false non-links between records representing the same entity.

False links can lead to erroneous estimates of the associations of interest (Neter etÂ al.,, 1965). For instance, in linear regression models, false links can induce attenuation bias when estimating the regression coefficients (Wang etÂ al.,, 2022; Patki and Shapiro,, 2023). False links can also have implications when estimating causal effects (Wortman and Reiter,, 2018), mortality rates (Krewski etÂ al.,, 2005), and population sizes (Isaki and Schultz,, 1987; Di Consiglio and Tuoto,, 2015, 2018). False non-links reduce the number of records available for analysis, leading to a loss in statistical power and increased variability in estimates (Haas etÂ al.,, 1994; Harron etÂ al.,, 2017). False non-links can also induce selection bias in the post-linkage inferences. Selection bias occurs when particular groups of records are less likely to link, and are thus excluded from the analysis (Lariscy,, 2011; Bohensky,, 2015; Reiter,, 2021).

The extent of errors in a linked file is determined by the degree of information contained in the linking variables. This information can be summarized in terms of two metrics: the reliability and the discriminatory power (Shlomo,, 2019).

The reliability is the probability that a linking variable is similar, given that a record pair is a link. Reliability reflects the quality of the linking variable, and is diminished when there is measurement error or missingness. For records iâˆˆğ€ğ‘–ğ€i\in\mathbf{A} and jâˆˆğğ‘—ğj\in\mathbf{B}, the aggregate reliability across all linking variables is quantified by mâ€‹(Î³iâ€‹j)ğ‘šsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘—m(\gamma_{ij}) (Shlomo,, 2019). Low reliability of the linking variables is typically associated with a higher proportion of false non-links (Tromp etÂ al.,, 2006, 2011). The discriminatory power is the probability that a linking variable is similar, given that a record pair is a non-link (Doidge and Harron,, 2018). The theoretical number of possible values of the linking variable, and their empirical distribution, determines this probability. The combined discriminatory power of all linking variables is quantified by uâ€‹(Î³iâ€‹j)ğ‘¢subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘—u(\gamma_{ij}) (Shlomo,, 2019). If the combined discriminatory power is low, the record linkage algorithm may identify a high proportion of false links (Tromp etÂ al.,, 2006, 2011).

Both these metrics have been used to assess the feasibility and performance of the FS model (Roos etÂ al.,, 1992; Cook etÂ al.,, 2001). Modifications to the FS weights based on the discriminatory power have also been proposed (Yancey,, 2000; Winkler,, 2000; Zhu etÂ al.,, 2009; Xu etÂ al.,, 2021; Vo etÂ al.,, 2023).

1.1.4 Blocking

With large file sizes, comparing all record pairs across the two files becomes computationally cumbersome. Large files also prompt a higher chance of occurrence of linkage errors (Wang etÂ al.,, 2022). To improve the scalability and accuracy of the linkage process, deterministic blocking is a commonly implemented pre-processing technique. In this technique, only those records that agree on predefined, highly accurate blocking variables are compared. Records that do not agree on these variables are considered non-links.

When utilizing deterministic blocking, it is important to ascertain an optimal block size, which often involves a cost-benefit trade-off (Baxter and Christen,, 2003). Large blocks generate a correspondingly large record comparison space, and may not provide substantial gains in computational efficiency or accuracy. When the blocks are too small, the record linking algorithm may miss many true links (Baxter and Christen,, 2003). Methods that utilize training data to determine optimum blocking schemes have been proposed as possible solutions (Bilenko etÂ al.,, 2006; Michelson and Knoblock,, 2006; Campbell etÂ al.,, 2021).

When blocking variables are error-prone, records may be placed in the wrong block, leading to linkage errors. Possible solutions include using multiple blocking passes (Baxter and Christen,, 2003), complex indexing schemes (Murray,, 2015), or a combination of deterministic and data-driven blocking (McVeigh etÂ al.,, 2020). Other alternatives include probabilistic blocking, which simultaneously infers the blocking scheme and the linkage parameters (Steorts etÂ al., 2014a, ). Probabilistic blocking can effectively propagate blocking uncertainty into the downstream statistical analysis (Marchant etÂ al.,, 2021).

When files are partitioned into deterministic blocks, typical practice is to implement the linkage algorithm independently within each block (Tancredi and Liseo,, 2011; Murray,, 2015; Sadinle,, 2017). However, it is also possible to allow the linkage algorithm to borrow information across blocks (Gutman etÂ al.,, 2013; Shan etÂ al.,, 2022).

Linking two files is commonly not the end goal in a study; rather, researchers may seek to estimate the population association between ğ˜A={ğ˜Aâ€‹i}subscriptğ˜ğ´subscriptğ˜ğ´ğ‘–\mathbf{Y}_{A}=\{\mathbf{Y}_{Ai}\} and ğ—B={ğ—Bâ€‹j}subscriptğ—ğµsubscriptğ—ğµğ‘—\mathbf{X}_{B}=\{\mathbf{X}_{Bj}\} among the nAâ€‹Bsubscriptğ‘›ğ´ğµn_{AB} overlapping records. One approach to summarizing this association is describing the conditional mean ğ”¼â¡(ğ˜A|ğ—B)=Î¼â€‹(ğ—B;ğœ·)ğ”¼conditionalsubscriptğ˜ğ´subscriptğ—ğµğœ‡subscriptğ—ğµğœ·\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\mathbf{Y}_{A}|\mathbf{X}_{B})=\mu(\mathbf{X}_{B};\boldsymbol{\beta}), where Î¼(.)\mu(.) denotes an inverse link function of known form, and ğœ·=(Î²1,â€¦,Î²PB)\boldsymbol{\beta}=(\beta_{1},\dots,\beta_{P{{}_{B}}}) is a set of parameters that includes the estimand of interest. Alternatively, the association can be summarized using correlation coefficients, principal components analysis, or other multivariate analysis techniques (Rencher,, 2002).

1.2.1 A taxonomy of linkage mechanisms

A linkage mechanism characterizes the relationship between the linkage structure and the variables in the individual files. There are broad parallels between missing data mechanisms (Rubin,, 1976), and linkage mechanisms. For a given prior on ğš«ğš«\boldsymbol{\Delta}, we define four mechanisms that describe fâ€‹(ğš«|ğ‹A,ğ‹B,ğ˜A,ğ—B,ğœ½)ğ‘“conditionalğš«subscriptğ‹ğ´subscriptğ‹ğµsubscriptğ˜ğ´subscriptğ—ğµğœ½f(\boldsymbol{\Delta}|\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B},\mathbf{Y}_{A},\mathbf{X}_{B},\boldsymbol{\theta}), where ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta} is a vector parameter governing the distribution. The definitions assume that ğ‹A,ğ‹B,ğ˜A,Â andÂ â€‹ğ—Bsubscriptğ‹ğ´subscriptğ‹ğµsubscriptğ˜ğ´Â andÂ subscriptğ—ğµ\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B},\mathbf{Y}_{A},\text{ and }\mathbf{X}_{B} are fully observed.

Definition 1.1.

Strongly non-informative linkage (SNL): The linkage mechanism is said to be strongly non-informative, if the conditional distribution of ğš«ğš«\boldsymbol{\Delta} given ğ‹A,ğ‹B,ğ˜A,ğ—Bsubscriptğ‹ğ´subscriptğ‹ğµsubscriptğ˜ğ´subscriptğ—ğµ\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B},\mathbf{Y}_{A},\mathbf{X}_{B} depends exclusively on ğ‹Aâ€‹Â andÂ â€‹ğ‹Bsubscriptğ‹ğ´Â andÂ subscriptğ‹ğµ\mathbf{L}_{A}\text{ and }\mathbf{L}_{B}. Formally, fâ€‹(ğš«|ğ‹A,ğ‹B,ğ˜A,ğ—B,ğœ½)=fâ€‹(ğš«|ğ‹A,ğ‹B,ğœ½)ğ‘“conditionalğš«subscriptğ‹ğ´subscriptğ‹ğµsubscriptğ˜ğ´subscriptğ—ğµğœ½ğ‘“conditionalğš«subscriptğ‹ğ´subscriptğ‹ğµğœ½f(\boldsymbol{\Delta}|\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B},\mathbf{Y}_{A},\mathbf{X}_{B},\boldsymbol{\theta})=f(\boldsymbol{\Delta}|\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B},\boldsymbol{\theta}) for all ğ˜A,ğ—B,subscriptğ˜ğ´subscriptğ—ğµ\mathbf{Y}_{A},\mathbf{X}_{B}, and ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}.

The SNL mechanism asserts that variables exclusive to each of the files do not inform the linkage. This has analogies to when the data are missing at random (MAR) (Rubin,, 1976). Specifically, SNL can be viewed as a special case of MAR, where the missingness is determined by a set of auxiliary variables ğ‹Asubscriptğ‹ğ´\mathbf{L}_{A} and ğ‹Bsubscriptğ‹ğµ\mathbf{L}_{B}. These variables may not inherently be of interest in the analysis, but predict the missingness (Schafer,, 1997; Collins etÂ al.,, 2001).

A more restrictive version of SNL states that the linkage is completely independent of ğ‹A,ğ‹B,ğ˜A,ğ—Bsubscriptğ‹ğ´subscriptğ‹ğµsubscriptğ˜ğ´subscriptğ—ğµ\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B},\mathbf{Y}_{A},\mathbf{X}_{B}. Thus, fâ€‹(ğš«|ğ‹A,ğ‹B,ğ˜A,ğ—B,ğœ½)=fâ€‹(ğš«|ğœ½)ğ‘“conditionalğš«subscriptğ‹ğ´subscriptğ‹ğµsubscriptğ˜ğ´subscriptğ—ğµğœ½ğ‘“conditionalğš«ğœ½f(\boldsymbol{\Delta}|\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B},\mathbf{Y}_{A},\mathbf{X}_{B},\boldsymbol{\theta})=f(\boldsymbol{\Delta}|\boldsymbol{\theta}) for all ğ‹A,ğ‹B,ğ˜Asubscriptğ‹ğ´subscriptğ‹ğµsubscriptğ˜ğ´\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B},\mathbf{Y}_{A}, ğ—B,subscriptğ—ğµ\mathbf{X}_{B}, and ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}. Han and Lahiri, (2019) refer to this as linkage completely at random (LCAR), similar to when the data are missing completely at random (MCAR) (Rubin,, 1976). A special case of the LCAR mechanism is when fâ€‹(ğš«|ğœ½)ğ‘“conditionalğš«ğœ½f(\boldsymbol{\Delta}|\boldsymbol{\theta}) is a constant. This mechanism is seldom plausible in practice, as it entails that every record pair has an equal probability of being a link.

Definition 1.2.

Non-informative linkage (NL): The linkage mechanism is said to be non-informative, if the conditional distribution of ğš«ğš«\boldsymbol{\Delta} given ğ‹A,ğ‹B,ğ˜A,ğ—Bsubscriptğ‹ğ´subscriptğ‹ğµsubscriptğ˜ğ´subscriptğ—ğµ\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B},\mathbf{Y}_{A},\mathbf{X}_{B} depends on ğ‹A,ğ‹Bsubscriptğ‹ğ´subscriptğ‹ğµ\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B} and ğ—Bsubscriptğ—ğµ\mathbf{X}_{B}, but not the outcome ğ˜Asubscriptğ˜ğ´\mathbf{Y}_{A}. Formally, fâ€‹(ğš«|ğ‹A,ğ‹B,ğ˜A,ğ—B,ğœ½)=fâ€‹(ğš«|ğ‹A,ğ‹B,ğ—B,ğœ½)ğ‘“conditionalğš«subscriptğ‹ğ´subscriptğ‹ğµsubscriptğ˜ğ´subscriptğ—ğµğœ½ğ‘“conditionalğš«subscriptğ‹ğ´subscriptğ‹ğµsubscriptğ—ğµğœ½f(\boldsymbol{\Delta}|\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B},\mathbf{Y}_{A},\mathbf{X}_{B},\boldsymbol{\theta})=f(\boldsymbol{\Delta}|\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B},\mathbf{X}_{B},\boldsymbol{\theta}) for all ğ˜Asubscriptğ˜ğ´\mathbf{Y}_{A} and ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}.

Post-linkage analysis methods with limited access to the linkage process (for e.g., Lahiri and Larsen,, 2005) typically rely on this assumption for inference. Han and Lahiri, (2019) refer to the NL mechanism as linkage at random (LAR).

To exemplify an NL scenario, suppose that file ğğ\mathbf{B} contains the covariate age, and file ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A} is a subset of units in file ğğ\mathbf{B} that are less than 60 years old. While age is not a linking variable common to both files, it implicitly informs the linkage. The NL mechanism is also a special case of the MAR mechanism, where auxiliary variables ğ‹Asubscriptğ‹ğ´\mathbf{L}_{A} and ğ‹Bsubscriptğ‹ğµ\mathbf{L}_{B}, and substantively important variables ğ—Bsubscriptğ—ğµ\mathbf{X}_{B}, inform the linkage.

Definition 1.3.

Weakly non-informative linkage (WNL): The linkage mechanism is said to be weakly non-informative, if fâ€‹(ğš«|ğ‹A,ğ‹B,ğ˜A,ğ—B,ğœ½)ğ‘“conditionalğš«subscriptğ‹ğ´subscriptğ‹ğµsubscriptğ˜ğ´subscriptğ—ğµğœ½f(\boldsymbol{\Delta}|\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B},\mathbf{Y}_{A},\mathbf{X}_{B},\boldsymbol{\theta}) depends on ğ‹A,ğ‹B,ğ˜A,Â andÂ â€‹ğ—Bsubscriptğ‹ğ´subscriptğ‹ğµsubscriptğ˜ğ´Â andÂ subscriptğ—ğµ\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B},\mathbf{Y}_{A},\text{ and }\mathbf{X}_{B}, for all ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}.

The WNL mechanism is also comparable to the MAR mechanism, as only fully observed variables inform the linkage.

Definition 1.4.

Informative linkage (IL): The linkage mechanism is said to be informative, if none of the above linkage mechanisms hold. For instance, the conditional distribution of ğš«ğš«\boldsymbol{\Delta} may depend on extraneous variables not observed in either file.

IL may induce bias in the post-linkage inferences, particularly if such extraneous variables are associated with the substantively important variables. The IL mechanism is comparable to the missing not at random (MNAR) mechanism (Rubin,, 1976), as the linkage status depends on unobserved quantities.

In what follows, we discuss linked-data inferential methods that rely on one or more of the linkage mechanisms as their underlying assumptions.

2 Primary analysis of linked files

Primary analysis refers to the situation when the record linkage and the post-linkage analysis are performed by the same individual. Alternatively, the analyst has access to files ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A} and ğğ\mathbf{B}, or to the likelihood of every record pair (iâˆˆğ€,jâˆˆğ)formulae-sequenceğ‘–ğ€ğ‘—ğ(i\in\mathbf{A},j\in\mathbf{B}) being a link. Following the missing data literature (Molenberghs etÂ al.,, 2014; Little and Rubin,, 2019), we classify primary analysis methods into three broad categories: likelihood and Bayesian methods, imputation methods, and weighting methods. We note that this classification can be overlapping. For instance, some methods can be classified as being both Bayesian and imputation-based, as proper MI methods commonly rely on sampling from (approximate) Bayesian posterior distributions (Rubin,, 1996).

The posterior distribution of the linkage structure, ğ’«â€‹(ğš«|ğ‹A,ğ‹B)âˆâ„’lâ€‹(ğ‹A,ğ‹B|ğš«)â€‹Ï€Î”â€‹(ğš«)proportional-toğ’«conditionalğš«subscriptğ‹ğ´subscriptğ‹ğµsubscriptâ„’ğ‘™subscriptğ‹ğ´conditionalsubscriptğ‹ğµğš«subscriptğœ‹Î”ğš«\mathcal{P}(\boldsymbol{\Delta}|\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B})\propto\mathcal{L}_{l}(\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B}|\boldsymbol{\Delta})\pi_{\Delta}(\boldsymbol{\Delta}), can be specified using one of two approaches: direct modeling of the information in ğ‹Aâ€‹Â andÂ â€‹ğ‹Bsubscriptğ‹ğ´Â andÂ subscriptğ‹ğµ\mathbf{L}_{A}\text{ and }\mathbf{L}_{B}, or using comparison vectors.

The direct modeling approach for ğ’«â€‹(ğš«|ğ‹A,ğ‹B)ğ’«conditionalğš«subscriptğ‹ğ´subscriptğ‹ğµ\mathcal{P}(\boldsymbol{\Delta}|\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B}) assumes that the linking variables ğ‹Asubscriptğ‹ğ´\mathbf{L}_{A} and ğ‹Bsubscriptğ‹ğµ\mathbf{L}_{B} are erroneous versions of their true latent values. Under the assumption of bipartite linkage, Tancredi and Liseo, (2011) utilize a hierarchical generative model to specify â„’lâ€‹(ğ‹A,ğ‹B|ğš«)subscriptâ„’ğ‘™subscriptğ‹ğ´conditionalsubscriptğ‹ğµğš«\mathcal{L}_{l}(\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B}|\boldsymbol{\Delta}). The model posits that ğ‹Aâ€‹isubscriptğ‹ğ´ğ‘–\mathbf{L}_{Ai} and ğ‹Bâ€‹jsubscriptğ‹ğµğ‘—\mathbf{L}_{Bj} are noisy realizations of the variables ğœ¼Asubscriptğœ¼ğ´\boldsymbol{\eta}_{A} and ğœ¼Bsubscriptğœ¼ğµ\boldsymbol{\eta}_{B}, which are independent realizations of a latent variable ğœ¼ğœ¼\boldsymbol{\eta}, with a discrete and finite support. Conditional on ğœ¼Asubscriptğœ¼ğ´\boldsymbol{\eta}_{A} and ğœ¼Bsubscriptğœ¼ğµ\boldsymbol{\eta}_{B}, ğ‹Aâ€‹isubscriptğ‹ğ´ğ‘–\mathbf{L}_{Ai} and ğ‹Bâ€‹jsubscriptğ‹ğµğ‘—\mathbf{L}_{Bj} follow an identifiable variant of the hit-and-miss model (Copas and Hilton,, 1990; Swartz etÂ al.,, 2004). This is a mixture distribution with two components: a point mass at the true values of ğ‹Aâ€‹isubscriptğ‹ğ´ğ‘–\mathbf{L}_{Ai} or ğ‹Bâ€‹jsubscriptğ‹ğµğ‘—\mathbf{L}_{Bj}, and a uniform distribution over the remaining points in the support of ğœ¼ğœ¼\boldsymbol{\eta}. At the top level of the hierarchy, a distribution for ğœ¼Asubscriptğœ¼ğ´\boldsymbol{\eta}_{A} and ğœ¼Bsubscriptğœ¼ğµ\boldsymbol{\eta}_{B} given ğš«ğš«\boldsymbol{\Delta} is postulated. The number of links nAâ€‹B=âˆ‘iâˆ‘jÎ”iâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘›ğ´ğµsubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘—subscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘—n_{AB}=\sum_{i}\sum_{j}\Delta_{ij} is treated as a random quantity. Under diffuse prior distributions on nAâ€‹Bsubscriptğ‘›ğ´ğµn_{AB} and ğš«ğš«\boldsymbol{\Delta}, the joint posterior distribution is explored via Metropolis-within-Gibbs algorithms (Robert and Casella,, 1999).

Steorts etÂ al., (2016) build on the measurement error model of Hall and Fienberg, (2012), and posit a likelihood for a bipartite graph that maps every record to a latent population entity. Akin to Tancredi and Liseo, (2011), the likelihood postulates that the linking variables are noisy representations of latent, multinomial random variables. The prior distribution on the linkage structure is assumed to be uniform, and posterior sampling is accomplished via Metropolis-within-Gibbs algorithms with split-merge proposal moves (Steorts etÂ al., 2014b, ). Linking records to latent entities, rather than to other records, allows the model to handle linkage of multiple files, and duplicates within a file.

The original methodologies of Tancredi and Liseo, (2011) and Steorts etÂ al., (2016) are restricted to categorical linking variables. Extensions to incorporate multivariate normal linking variables (Liseo and Tancredi,, 2011), and string-valued linking variables (Steorts,, 2015) have also been proposed.

In some applications, it may be difficult to directly model complex linking variables, like addresses or telephone numbers. A solution is to define the likelihood â„’lâ€‹(ğ‹A,ğ‹B|ğš«)subscriptâ„’ğ‘™subscriptğ‹ğ´conditionalsubscriptğ‹ğµğš«\mathcal{L}_{l}(\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B}|\boldsymbol{\Delta}) using comparison vectors Î³iâ€‹jsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘—\gamma_{ij} (Section 1.1.2). Akin to the FS model, the comparison vectors are assumed to follow a mixture distribution over the set of links and non-links. However, bipartite linkage is explicitly enforced via a prior distribution on ğš«ğš«\boldsymbol{\Delta}. This approach was developed by Fortini etÂ al., (2001) and Larsen, (2002, 2005) for the case of binary comparison vectors. Sadinle, (2017) extended it to include partial agreements on complex linking variables, and to accommodate ignorable missingness (Rubin,, 1976) in the linking variables. Formally, the model is

2.1.2 Likelihood and Bayesian inference under WNL

The linkage averaging approach in Equation (6) can propagate linkage uncertainty to the downstream analysis. However, information from the analysis models is not utilized in the linkage process. An alternative is to allow the analysis models to inform the linkage. In a Bayesian framework, this can be accomplished by sampling ğš«ğš«\boldsymbol{\Delta} and ğœ·ğœ·\boldsymbol{\beta} simultaneously from their joint posterior distribution (Equation (5)).

It has been shown analytically, and via simulations, that incorporating substantive relationships into the linkage process can facilitate correct identification of links and non-links (Kamat etÂ al.,, 2023). These improvements are commonly called the â€œfeedback effectâ€ of the post-linkage analysis model (Steorts etÂ al.,, 2018). The magnitude of the improvements can depend on (i) fit of the specified likelihood â„’aâ€‹(ğ˜A,ğ—B|ğ‹A,ğ‹B,ğš«,ğœ·)subscriptâ„’ğ‘subscriptğ˜ğ´conditionalsubscriptğ—ğµsubscriptğ‹ğ´subscriptğ‹ğµğš«ğœ·\mathcal{L}_{a}(\mathbf{Y}_{A},\mathbf{X}_{B}|\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B},\boldsymbol{\Delta},\boldsymbol{\beta}); and (ii) the strength of the association between ğ˜Asubscriptğ˜ğ´\mathbf{Y}_{A} and ğ—Bsubscriptğ—ğµ\mathbf{X}_{B}.

Sampling from the joint posterior distribution in Equation (5) can be accomplished via the DA algorithm. At the mtâ€‹hsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘¡â„m^{th} iteration, this algorithm iterates between two steps: (i) I-Step: Impute ğš«(m)superscriptğš«ğ‘š\boldsymbol{\Delta}^{(m)} from the posterior full conditional distribution ğ’«â€‹(ğš«|ğ‹A,ğ‹B,ğ˜A,ğ—B,ğœ·(mâˆ’1))ğ’«conditionalğš«subscriptğ‹ğ´subscriptğ‹ğµsubscriptğ˜ğ´subscriptğ—ğµsuperscriptğœ·ğ‘š1\mathcal{P}(\boldsymbol{\Delta}|\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B},\mathbf{Y}_{A},\mathbf{X}_{B},\boldsymbol{\beta}^{(m-1)}); and (ii) P-step: Sample ğœ·(m)superscriptğœ·ğ‘š\boldsymbol{\beta}^{(m)} from the posterior full conditional distribution ğ’«â€‹(ğœ·|ğ‹A,ğ‹B,ğ˜A,ğ—B,ğš«(m))ğ’«conditionalğœ·subscriptğ‹ğ´subscriptğ‹ğµsubscriptğ˜ğ´subscriptğ—ğµsuperscriptğš«ğ‘š\mathcal{P}(\boldsymbol{\beta}|\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B},\mathbf{Y}_{A},\mathbf{X}_{B},\boldsymbol{\Delta}^{(m)}). The resultant samples of ğœ·ğœ·\boldsymbol{\beta} incorporate the uncertainty around ğš«ğš«\boldsymbol{\Delta}, and can be used for point and interval estimation.

Gutman etÂ al., (2013) model the associations between variables common to both files, and those exclusive to either file. High quality linking variables are utilized in an informative blocking step, which reduces the computational complexity. Within each block, the linkage is assumed to be bipartite and complete, so that every record in the smaller block can be linked to a unique record in the larger block. The linkage likelihood â„’lâ€‹(ğ‹A,ğ‹B|ğš«)subscriptâ„’ğ‘™subscriptğ‹ğ´conditionalsubscriptğ‹ğµğš«\mathcal{L}_{l}(\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B}|\boldsymbol{\Delta}) is defined using a joint distribution that describes inconsistently recorded linking variables. The distributional form of â„’aâ€‹(ğ˜A,ğ—B|ğ‹A,ğ‹B,ğš«,ğœ·)subscriptâ„’ğ‘subscriptğ˜ğ´conditionalsubscriptğ—ğµsubscriptğ‹ğ´subscriptğ‹ğµğš«ğœ·\mathcal{L}_{a}(\mathbf{Y}_{A},\mathbf{X}_{B}|\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B},\boldsymbol{\Delta},\boldsymbol{\beta}) is specific to the application, and can include models of scientific interest, and models for relationships that only inform the linkage. For unlinked records in the larger block, variables in the smaller block are treated as missing data, and imputed as part of an overarching DA scheme. Under a uniform prior on ğš«ğš«\boldsymbol{\Delta}, posterior sampling for ğš«ğš«\boldsymbol{\Delta} is accomplished via Metropolis algorithms. Dalzell and Reiter, (2018) extend the model of Gutman etÂ al., (2013) to incorporate erroneous blocking variables, and to allow individual records to shift between blocks.

A limitation of the approach of Gutman etÂ al., (2013) is the assumption of complete linkage, which can be violated in practice. An alternative approach augments the Bayesian FS likelihood (Equation (8)) with relationships between variables exclusive to either file (Tang etÂ al.,, 2020; Kamat etÂ al.,, 2023). Bayesian generative models have also been applied in a joint modeling framework, in the context of linear regression (Tancredi and Liseo,, 2015; Steorts etÂ al.,, 2018), and small area estimation (Briscolini etÂ al.,, 2018).

Hof and Zwinderman, (2014) propose to estimate ğœ·ğœ·\boldsymbol{\beta} by maximizing the complete-data likelihood â„’csubscriptâ„’ğ‘\mathcal{L}_{c}, over all possible values of ğš«ğš«\boldsymbol{\Delta}. Since the parameter space of ğš«ğš«\boldsymbol{\Delta} is fairly large, maximizing â„’csubscriptâ„’ğ‘\mathcal{L}_{c} can be computationally prohibitive. As a solution, Hof and Zwinderman, (2014) propose a two-step pseudo-likelihood approach to estimate ğœ·ğœ·\boldsymbol{\beta}. In the first step, estimates of the linking probabilities for all record pairs are computed under the FS model. These estimates are treated as fixed constants in the pseudo-likelihood. In the second step, the pseudo-likelihood is maximized using the EM algorithm, to obtain an estimate ğœ·^bold-^ğœ·\boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}. The sampling variance of ğœ·^bold-^ğœ·\boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}, and confidence intervals for ğœ·ğœ·\boldsymbol{\beta}, can be computed using the Bootstrap, or an asymptotic normal approximation for the sampling distribution of ğœ·^bold-^ğœ·\boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}. A similar inferential approach for time-to-event data has been proposed in Hof etÂ al., (2017).

2.2 Imputation

Fully Bayesian approaches to estimating ğœ·ğœ·\boldsymbol{\beta} can propagate linkage uncertainty in a principled manner, but are computationally intensive. Moreover, in a joint modeling framework, the models used in the linkage, namely â„’aâ€‹(ğ˜A,ğ—B|ğ‹A,ğ‹B,ğš«,ğœ·)subscriptâ„’ğ‘subscriptğ˜ğ´conditionalsubscriptğ—ğµsubscriptğ‹ğ´subscriptğ‹ğµğš«ğœ·\mathcal{L}_{a}(\mathbf{Y}_{A},\mathbf{X}_{B}|\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B},\boldsymbol{\Delta},\boldsymbol{\beta}), may differ from the scientific model of interest. In such situations, an alternative is to approximate a fully Bayesian analysis using multiple imputation (MI) (Rubin,, 1987).

In MI, M>1ğ‘€1M>1 imputations of the linkage structure are generated from its posterior distribution. Each imputation is analyzed separately, and estimates are pooled across the imputations using common combination rules (Rubin,, 1987; Little and Rubin,, 2019). This procedure can propagate linkage uncertainty into the downstream analysis, while simplifying the computation. Application of MI to linked-data inference has been exemplified in Gutman etÂ al., (2013), Abowd etÂ al., (2021), and Shan etÂ al., (2021), among others.

Formally, in each of the Mğ‘€M posterior samples of the linkage structure, ğš«(1),â€¦,ğš«(M)superscriptğš«1â€¦superscriptğš«ğ‘€\boldsymbol{\Delta}^{(1)},\dots,\boldsymbol{\Delta}^{(M)}, we obtain a point estimate, ğœ·^(m)superscriptbold-^ğœ·ğ‘š\boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}^{(m)}, and its sampling variance U(m)superscriptğ‘ˆğ‘šU^{(m)}, for m=1,â€¦,Mğ‘š1â€¦ğ‘€m=1,\dots,M. A point estimate for ğœ·ğœ·\boldsymbol{\beta} across the Mğ‘€M linked files is ğœ·^=Mâˆ’1â€‹âˆ‘m=1Mğœ·^(m)bold-^ğœ·superscriptğ‘€1superscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ‘€superscriptbold-^ğœ·ğ‘š\boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}=M^{-1}\sum_{m=1}^{M}\boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}^{(m)}. Its estimated variance is TM=UÂ¯M+(1+Mâˆ’1)â€‹BMsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘€subscriptÂ¯ğ‘ˆğ‘€1superscriptğ‘€1subscriptğµğ‘€T_{M}=\bar{U}_{M}+(1+M^{-1})B_{M}, where UÂ¯M=Mâˆ’1â€‹âˆ‘m=1MU(m)subscriptÂ¯ğ‘ˆğ‘€superscriptğ‘€1superscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ‘€superscriptğ‘ˆğ‘š\bar{U}_{M}=M^{-1}\sum_{m=1}^{M}U^{(m)} and BM=(Mâˆ’1)âˆ’1â€‹âˆ‘m=1M(ğœ·^(m)âˆ’ğœ·^)2subscriptğµğ‘€superscriptğ‘€11superscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ‘€superscriptsuperscriptbold-^ğœ·ğ‘šbold-^ğœ·2B_{M}=(M-1)^{-1}\sum_{m=1}^{M}(\boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}^{(m)}-\boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}})^{2}. A confidence interval for ğœ·^bold-^ğœ·\boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}} can be constructed using a Studentâ€™s-tğ‘¡t approximation, (ğœ·^âˆ’ğœ·)/TMâˆ¼tÎ½similar-tobold-^ğœ·ğœ·subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘€subscriptğ‘¡ğœˆ(\boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}-\boldsymbol{\beta})/\sqrt{T_{M}}\sim t_{\nu}, where Î½=(Mâˆ’1)â€‹(1+UÂ¯M/((1+Mâˆ’1)â€‹BM))2ğœˆğ‘€1superscript1subscriptÂ¯ğ‘ˆğ‘€1superscriptğ‘€1subscriptğµğ‘€2\nu=(M-1)(1+\bar{U}_{M}/((1+M^{-1})B_{M}))^{2} (Rubin,, 1987).

A limitation of MI is that the imputation model for ğš«ğš«\boldsymbol{\Delta} may be uncongenial (Meng,, 1994; Xie and Meng,, 2017) to the post-linkage analysis model. The analysis model is congenial to the imputation model, if there exists a unifying Bayesian model for the complete data that embeds both of them (Murray,, 2018). An uncongenial imputation model may lead to biased point estimates, and interval estimates with invalid coverages (van Buuren,, 2018). Since congeniality is hard to ascertain in practice, a general solution is to use an imputation model that is less restrictive than the analysis model. Thus, it may be advisable to include as many relationships of substantive interest as possible in the imputation model for ğš«ğš«\boldsymbol{\Delta} (Rubin,, 1996; Xie and Meng,, 2017). The joint modeling approaches in Section 2.1.2 can provide a way to accomplish this.

Goldstein etÂ al., (2012) propose to cast linking two files in a statistical matching framework (Dâ€™Orazio etÂ al.,, 2006). In this framework, all records in file ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A} have ğ—Bsubscriptğ—ğµ\mathbf{X}_{B} missing. For record iâˆˆğ€ğ‘–ğ€i\in\mathbf{A}, all records in file ğğ\mathbf{B} serve as a pool of candidate donors. Each imputed file is analyzed separately, and estimates are pooled using MI combining rules.

The imputation model pB|Asubscriptğ‘conditionalğµğ´p_{B|A} assumes joint multivariate normality of (ğ˜A,ğ—B,ğ‹A,ğ‹B)subscriptğ˜ğ´subscriptğ—ğµsubscriptğ‹ğ´subscriptğ‹ğµ(\mathbf{Y}_{A},\mathbf{X}_{B},\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B}), when all variables are continuous. When the data comprise a mix of continuous and categorical variables, pB|Asubscriptğ‘conditionalğµğ´p_{B|A} is derived using latent normal models (Goldstein etÂ al.,, 2009).

One limitation of the algorithm is that a set of known links is required to estimate the parameters in pB|Aâ€‹(ğ—B|ğ˜A,ğ‹A,ğ‹B)subscriptğ‘conditionalğµğ´conditionalsubscriptğ—ğµsubscriptğ˜ğ´subscriptğ‹ğ´subscriptğ‹ğµp_{B|A}(\mathbf{X}_{B}|\mathbf{Y}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{B}). Such a set is not always available in practice. Moreover, the imputation procedure produces statistically valid estimates, as long as the linkage errors are independent of ğ—Bsubscriptğ—ğµ\mathbf{X}_{B} given ğ˜A,ğ‹A,Â andÂ â€‹ğ‹Bsubscriptğ˜ğ´subscriptğ‹ğ´Â andÂ subscriptğ‹ğµ\mathbf{Y}_{A},\mathbf{L}_{A},\text{ and }\mathbf{L}_{B}. This is equivalent to ğ—Bsubscriptğ—ğµ\mathbf{X}_{B} being missing at random (Goldstein etÂ al.,, 2012). Violation of this assumption can lead to substantial bias in point estimates (Harron etÂ al.,, 2014). A possible mitigation strategy is to make the MAR assumption more plausible, by specifying rich imputation models that accommodate variables from auxiliary data sources (Goldstein and Harron,, 2015).

2.3 Weighting

Weighting methods aim to obtain unbiased parameter estimates of generalized linear models fit with linked data. These methods are confined to scenarios where a univariate response ğ˜Asubscriptğ˜ğ´\mathbf{Y}_{A} is regressed on a set of covariates ğ—Bsubscriptğ—ğµ\mathbf{X}_{B}. Weighting methods rely on two assumptions. The first assumption is that the linkage is complete, i.e., the smaller file ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A} is a subset of the larger file ğğ\mathbf{B}, so that nAâ€‹B=nAsubscriptğ‘›ğ´ğµsubscriptğ‘›ğ´n_{AB}=n_{A}. The second assumption is that the linkage mechanism is NL.

For the identity link function, Î¼â€‹(ğ—B;ğœ·)=ğ—Bâ€‹ğœ·ğœ‡subscriptğ—ğµğœ·subscriptğ—ğµğœ·\mu(\mathbf{X}_{B};{\boldsymbol{\beta}})=\mathbf{X}_{B}{\boldsymbol{\beta}}, and equally sized files, setting Ï…â€‹(ğ—B;ğœ·)=ğ—BTâ€‹ğTğœsubscriptğ—ğµğœ·superscriptsubscriptğ—ğµğ‘‡superscriptğğ‘‡\upsilon(\mathbf{X}_{B};{\boldsymbol{\beta}})=\mathbf{X}_{B}^{T}\mathbf{Q}^{T}, yields the estimator ğœ·^Lâ€‹L=(ğ—BTâ€‹ğTâ€‹ğğ—B)âˆ’1â€‹ğ—BTâ€‹ğTâ€‹ğ˜Aâˆ—superscript^ğœ·ğ¿ğ¿superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ—ğµğ‘‡superscriptğğ‘‡subscriptğğ—ğµ1superscriptsubscriptğ—ğµğ‘‡superscriptğğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ˜ğ´\hat{{\boldsymbol{\beta}}}^{LL}=(\mathbf{X}_{B}^{T}\mathbf{Q}^{T}\mathbf{Q}\mathbf{X}_{B})^{-1}\mathbf{X}_{B}^{T}\mathbf{Q}^{T}\mathbf{Y}_{A}^{*} (Lahiri and Larsen,, 2005). Alternatively, ğœ·^Lâ€‹Lsuperscript^ğœ·ğ¿ğ¿\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}^{LL} can be obtained using a least squares regression of ğ˜Aâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ˜ğ´\mathbf{Y}_{A}^{*} on a weighted combination of the covariates, ğğ—Bsubscriptğğ—ğµ\mathbf{Q}\mathbf{X}_{B}.

The point estimator ğœ·^Lâ€‹Lsuperscript^ğœ·ğ¿ğ¿\hat{{\boldsymbol{\beta}}}^{LL} is unbiased when ğğ\mathbf{Q} is known. However, in most applications, only an estimate of ğğ\mathbf{Q} is available. When ğğ{\mathbf{Q}} is estimated using the FS model, its rows may not sum to one, as the one-to-one linkage constraint is not enforced. A possible solution is to normalize each entry in ğğ\mathbf{Q} as qiâ€‹jâ€²=qiâ€‹j/âˆ‘jâˆˆğqiâ€‹jsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘—ğsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—q^{{}^{\prime}}_{ij}=q_{ij}/\sum_{j\in\mathbf{B}}q_{ij}.

Chipperfield and Chambers, (2015) argue that using qiâ€‹jâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘–ğ‘—q^{{}^{\prime}}_{ij} can lead to biased inferences under one-to-one linkage. This limitation can be overcome by estimating ğğ\mathbf{Q} using a bootstrap for the entire linkage process (Winglee etÂ al.,, 2005; Chipperfield and Chambers,, 2015). Other variations of the weighting approach have been proposed, including using weighted least squares when covariates are spread over multiple files (Hof and Zwinderman,, 2012), and relaxing the assumption of complete linkage (Hof and Zwinderman,, 2012; Chipperfield and Chambers,, 2015).

Computation of variances with estimated weights is generally not straightforward (Little and Rubin,, 2019). Valid variance estimators require elaborate theoretical calculations (Tsiatis,, 2006), or computationally-intensive resampling techniques (Little and Rubin,, 2019). For particular choices of Ï…â€‹(ğ—B;ğœ·)ğœsubscriptğ—ğµğœ·\upsilon(\mathbf{X}_{B};\boldsymbol{\beta}), Han, (2018) derives theoretical plug-in estimators for the sampling variance of ğœ·^^ğœ·\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}} under Equation (12). To simplify calculations, Han, (2018) suggests truncating every row of ğğ\mathbf{Q} to include the highest (or two highest) values. These estimators, however, do not account for the uncertainty arising from using an estimate of ğğ\mathbf{Q}. This can be addressed by using resampling methods that re-estimate ğğ\mathbf{Q} at every iteration. Two such methods are based on the unified Jackknife theory (Jiang etÂ al.,, 2002; Han and Lahiri,, 2019), and the Bootstrap (Lahiri and Larsen,, 2005).

2.4 Interlude: Estimating complex models with linked files

A majority of the linked-data inferential methods in the literature center around estimating parameters of generalized linear models. Some work has also focused on inferring the size of a closed population, using capture-recapture (Fienberg,, 1972) or multiple-systems estimation (Bird and King,, 2018). For example, Bayesian models for concurrently inferring the linkage and the population size have been developed, for the case of two files (Tancredi and Liseo,, 2011), and multiple files (Tancredi etÂ al.,, 2020).

The Bayesian and imputation-based approaches also offer a flexible framework to estimate other complex models, such as hierarchical models (Gelman etÂ al.,, 2013), or multivariate analyses like finite mixture models (Peel and MachLachlan,, 2000). As some multivariate analysis methods are exploratory in nature (for e.g, factor analysis), posterior sampling within a fully Bayesian framework can be computationally daunting (Conti etÂ al.,, 2014). In such cases, an MI approach can offer more feasibility. In Section 4.2, we provide an example of using MI to perform model-based cluster analysis with a linked file.

3 Secondary analysis of linked files

Secondary analysis refers to settings when the linkage and the data analysis are performed by different individuals. Specifically, the data analyst is provided a linked file, but does not have access to the individual files, the linking variables, or linking probabilities for record pairs. This situation arises when the original data comprise sensitive information, and releasing individual files interferes with privacy regulations, or poses considerable disclosure risks (Gilbert etÂ al.,, 2017; Christen etÂ al.,, 2020).

In secondary analysis, the analyst does not have access to records that were left unlinked during the linkage process. Consequently, most analysis methods can only propagate the uncertainty due to false links. Inferences from the linked file may not be generalizable to the entire population of entities, without assumptions on the relationship between the linked and unlinked records, or availability of additional information about the unlinked records.

Formally, secondary analysis is based on the file ğ…â‰¡{ğ˜Aâ€‹l,ğ—Bâ€‹l}l=1nAâ€‹Bğ…superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ˜ğ´ğ‘™subscriptğ—ğµğ‘™ğ‘™1subscriptğ‘›ğ´ğµ\mathbf{F}\equiv\{\mathbf{Y}_{Al},\mathbf{X}_{Bl}\}_{l=1}^{n_{AB}}, obtained by linking files ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A} and ğğ\mathbf{B}. The file ğ…ğ…\mathbf{F} can be partitioned into true and false links, but this partitioning is unknown. In this case, we reformulate the linkage structure using a vector of indicators ğ‚={Cl}ğ‚subscriptğ¶ğ‘™\mathbf{C}=\{C_{l}\}, where Cl=1subscriptğ¶ğ‘™1C_{l}=1 if record pair lğ‘™l is a true link, and Cl=0subscriptğ¶ğ‘™0C_{l}=0, otherwise, where l=1,â€¦â€‹nAâ€‹Bğ‘™1â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ´ğµl=1,\dots n_{AB}.

3.1 Likelihood, Bayesian, and imputation methods

Under the WNL assumption, Gutman etÂ al., (2016) postulate that record pairs in ğ…ğ…\mathbf{F} are derived from a two-class mixture model. Formally, the likelihood is

ğ˜Aâ€‹l,ğ—Bâ€‹l|Cl=1âˆ¼â„’Mâ€‹(ğ˜Aâ€‹l,ğ—Bâ€‹l|ğœ·M),ğ˜Aâ€‹l,ğ—Bâ€‹l|Cl=0âˆ¼â„’Uâ€‹(ğ˜Aâ€‹l,ğ—Bâ€‹l|ğœ·U),Clâˆ¼iidâ€‹Â BernoulliÂ â€‹(Î»),formulae-sequencesubscriptğ˜ğ´ğ‘™conditionalsubscriptğ—ğµğ‘™subscriptğ¶ğ‘™1similar-tosubscriptâ„’ğ‘€subscriptğ˜ğ´ğ‘™conditionalsubscriptğ—ğµğ‘™subscriptğœ·ğ‘€subscriptğ˜ğ´ğ‘™conditionalsubscriptğ—ğµğ‘™subscriptğ¶ğ‘™0similar-tosubscriptâ„’ğ‘ˆsubscriptğ˜ğ´ğ‘™conditionalsubscriptğ—ğµğ‘™subscriptğœ·ğ‘ˆsubscriptğ¶ğ‘™iidsimilar-toÂ BernoulliÂ ğœ†\displaystyle\begin{split}\mathbf{Y}_{Al},\mathbf{X}_{Bl}|C_{l}=1&\sim\mathcal{L}_{M}(\mathbf{Y}_{Al},\mathbf{X}_{Bl}|{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{M}),\\ \mathbf{Y}_{Al},\mathbf{X}_{Bl}|C_{l}=0&\sim\mathcal{L}_{U}(\mathbf{Y}_{Al},\mathbf{X}_{Bl}|{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{U}),\\ C_{l}&\overset{\mathrm{iid}}{\sim}\text{ Bernoulli }(\lambda),\end{split} (13)

where ğœ·Msubscriptğœ·ğ‘€\boldsymbol{{\boldsymbol{\beta}}}_{M} and ğœ·Usubscriptğœ·ğ‘ˆ\boldsymbol{{\boldsymbol{\beta}}}_{U} are parameters governing the joint distribution of (ğ˜A,ğ—B)subscriptğ˜ğ´subscriptğ—ğµ(\mathbf{Y}_{A},\mathbf{X}_{B}) among the true and false links, respectively, and Î»ğœ†\lambda is the marginal probability of a true link. The models â„’Msubscriptâ„’ğ‘€\mathcal{L}_{M} and â„’Usubscriptâ„’ğ‘ˆ\mathcal{L}_{U} can be augmented to include additional variables present in the linked file.

To avoid label switching, Gutman etÂ al., (2016) rely on informative prior distributions for (ğœ·M,ğœ·U,Î»)subscriptğœ·ğ‘€subscriptğœ·ğ‘ˆğœ†({\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{M},{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{U},\lambda). These priors are constructed using a validation sample, and other available linkage paradata. The missing ğ‚ğ‚\mathbf{C} is imputed using a DA scheme, that iterates between sampling ğ‚ğ‚\mathbf{C}, and the parameters (ğœ·M,ğœ·U,Î»)subscriptğœ·ğ‘€subscriptğœ·ğ‘ˆğœ†(\boldsymbol{\beta}_{M},\boldsymbol{\beta}_{U},\lambda). When â„’Msubscriptâ„’ğ‘€\mathcal{L}_{M} represents the scientific model of interest, inference based on posterior samples of ğœ·Msubscriptğœ·ğ‘€{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{M} can account for the uncertainty around ğ‚ğ‚\mathbf{C}. Alternatively, each DA iteration provides a set of links, that can be used to fit the analysis model of interest. Point and interval estimates across posterior samples of ğ‚ğ‚\mathbf{C} can be obtained using the MI combining rules (Section 2.2).

Slawski etÂ al., (2021) consider the case of linear regression, and assume independence between ğ˜Aâ€‹lsubscriptğ˜ğ´ğ‘™\mathbf{Y}_{Al} and ğ—Bâ€‹lsubscriptğ—ğµğ‘™\mathbf{X}_{Bl} when postulating â„’Usubscriptâ„’ğ‘ˆ\mathcal{L}_{U} in Equation (13). An estimate ğœ·^Msubscript^ğœ·ğ‘€\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{M} is obtained by maximizing the likelihood in (13) using the EM algorithm. The variance of ğœ·^Msubscript^ğœ·ğ‘€\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{M} is approximated using the Huber-Sandwich estimator (Freedman,, 2006), and confidence intervals are constructed under an asymptotic normal approximation for the sampling distribution of ğœ·^Msubscript^ğœ·ğ‘€\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{M}.

3.2 Weighting

In a secondary analysis setting, the matrix ğğ\mathbf{Q} (Equation (9)) can only be modeled using coarse summary statistics from the linkage process. One such statistic is the overall proportion of correct links, Î»ğœ†\lambda. This can be calculated, for example, by comparing a representative audit sample from the linked file to a gold-standard linked file (Chambers and Diniz da Silva,, 2020).

Under the assumption that nA=nBsubscriptğ‘›ğ´subscriptğ‘›ğµn_{A}=n_{B}, and that the linkage is complete and one-to-one, Chambers, (2009) imposes an â€œexchangeableâ€ structure on ğğ\mathbf{Q}. Formally, the exchangeable linkage error (ELE) model is (Chambers,, 2009)

[ğ](iâˆˆğ€,jâˆˆğ)=[PrÂ â€‹(Î”iâ€‹j=1|ğ‹Aâ€‹i,ğ‹Bâ€‹j,ğ—Bâ€‹j)](iâˆˆğ€,jâˆˆğ)={Î»,Â ifÂ â€‹i=j1âˆ’Î»nAâˆ’1,Â ifÂ â€‹iâ‰ j.subscriptdelimited-[]ğformulae-sequenceğ‘–ğ€ğ‘—ğsubscriptdelimited-[]PrÂ subscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘—conditional1subscriptğ‹ğ´ğ‘–subscriptğ‹ğµğ‘—subscriptğ—ğµğ‘—formulae-sequenceğ‘–ğ€ğ‘—ğcasesğœ†Â ifÂ ğ‘–ğ‘—otherwise1ğœ†subscriptğ‘›ğ´1Â ifÂ ğ‘–ğ‘—otherwise\displaystyle\begin{split}[\mathbf{Q}]_{(i\in\mathbf{A},j\in\mathbf{B})}&=[\text{Pr }(\Delta_{ij}=1|\mathbf{L}_{Ai},\mathbf{L}_{Bj},\mathbf{X}_{Bj})]_{(i\in\mathbf{A},j\in\mathbf{B})}\\ &=\begin{cases}\lambda,\text{ if }i=j\\ \frac{1-\lambda}{n_{A}-1},\text{ if }i\neq j.\end{cases}\end{split} (14)

This construct implies that (i) every record jâˆˆğğ‘—ğj\in\mathbf{B} has probability Î»ğœ†\lambda of being the correct link for record iâˆˆğ€ğ‘–ğ€i\in\mathbf{A}, and (ii) any two records that are not linked to iâˆˆğ€ğ‘–ğ€i\in\mathbf{A} are equally likely to be the correct links.

Exchangeability implies that the linkage is independent of the linking and substantive variables, so that the linkage mechanism is LCAR. In many applications, this assumption may be overly stringent, as the probability of correct linkage can be heterogeneous across records (Winkler,, 2021). A possible solution is to assume that the linkage probabilities are homogeneous within disjoint subgroups (or blocks) of the linked file, rather than across all the linked records (Chambers and Diniz da Silva,, 2020).

For inference on ğœ·ğœ·\boldsymbol{\beta} in Equation (12), Chambers, (2009) proposes different types of weighting matrices Ï…â€‹(ğ—B;ğœ·)ğœsubscriptğ—ğµğœ·\upsilon(\mathbf{X}_{B};\boldsymbol{\beta}). In the case of linear regression, setting Ï…â€‹(ğ—B;ğœ·)=ğ—BâŠ¤ğœsubscriptğ—ğµğœ·superscriptsubscriptğ—ğµtop\upsilon(\mathbf{X}_{B};\boldsymbol{\beta})=\mathbf{X}_{B}^{\top} yields an estimator with a ratio-type bias correction, similar in spirit to Scheuren and Winkler, (1993). Setting Ï…â€‹(ğ—B;ğœ·)=ğ—BâŠ¤â€‹ğâŠ¤ğœsubscriptğ—ğµğœ·superscriptsubscriptğ—ğµtopsuperscriptğtop\upsilon(\mathbf{X}_{B};\boldsymbol{\beta})=\mathbf{X}_{B}^{\top}\mathbf{Q}^{\top}, yields the Lahiri-Larsen estimator, with ğğ\mathbf{Q} defined in Equation (14). Setting Ï…â€‹(ğ—B;ğœ·)=ğ—BâŠ¤â€‹ğâŠ¤â€‹(Ïƒ2â€‹ğˆnA+ğšº)âˆ’1ğœsubscriptğ—ğµğœ·superscriptsubscriptğ—ğµtopsuperscriptğtopsuperscriptsuperscriptğœ2subscriptğˆsubscriptğ‘›ğ´ğšº1\upsilon(\mathbf{X}_{B};\boldsymbol{\beta})=\mathbf{X}_{B}^{\top}\mathbf{Q}^{\top}(\sigma^{2}\mathbf{I}_{n_{A}}+\mathbf{\Sigma})^{-1}, where Ïƒ2=ğ•â¡(ğ˜A|ğ—B)superscriptğœ2ğ•conditionalsubscriptğ˜ğ´subscriptğ—ğµ\sigma^{2}=\operatorname{\mathbb{V}}(\mathbf{Y}_{A}|\mathbf{X}_{B}) and ğšº=ğ•â¡(ğš«â€‹ğ”¼â¡(ğ˜A|ğ—B)|ğ—B)ğšºğ•conditionalğš«ğ”¼conditionalsubscriptğ˜ğ´subscriptğ—ğµsubscriptğ—ğµ\mathbf{\Sigma}=\operatorname{\mathbb{V}}(\boldsymbol{\Delta}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\mathbf{Y}_{A}|\mathbf{X}_{B})|\mathbf{X}_{B}), yields the asymptotically efficient best linear unbiased estimator (BLUE) of ğœ·ğœ·\boldsymbol{\beta}. Corresponding estimators for the case of logistic regression have also been proposed in Chambers, (2009, pp.22-23). Chambers, (2009) derives Sandwich-type asymptotic sampling variances of these estimators, which account for the variability from using an estimate of Î»ğœ†\lambda.

Kim and Chambers, 2012a extend Equation (12) to the case of incomplete linkage, when some records from both files may remain unlinked. For valid inference, Kim and Chambers, 2012a assume ignorable non-linkage, which implies that unlinked records in each file are a random sample of all the records in that file. Equivalently, the relationship between ğ˜Aâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ˜ğ´\mathbf{Y}^{*}_{A} and ğ—Bsubscriptğ—ğµ\mathbf{X}_{B} is the same among linked and unlinked records. This assumption is equivalent to unit non-response in surveys occurring completely at random (Rubin,, 1976). When the non-linkage is not ignorable, Kim and Chambers, 2012a propose to adjust regression coefficient estimates using inverse probability weighting (Seaman and White,, 2011).

Zhang and Tuoto, (2021) use the ELE model to develop pseudo-OLS estimators for linear regression, that accommodate incomplete linkage and heterogeneous linkage probabilities. Other extensions of the ELE model include its application to multi-file linkage (Kim and Chambers, 2012b, ; Kim and Chambers,, 2015), to estimation of survey-weighted population totals (Chipperfield,, 2019), to survival analysis (Vo etÂ al.,, 2024), to robust regression in the presence of outliers (Chambers etÂ al.,, 2022), and to estimation using calibrated auxiliary information (Chambers and Diniz da Silva,, 2020). Sensitivity of the linear regression estimators to the ELE assumption has also been demonstrated, theoretically (Zhang and Tuoto,, 2021), and via simulations (Chambers etÂ al.,, 2019).

4 Simulation studies

We examine the performance of selected methods from Sections 2 and 3 using extensive simulations. These methods encompass a wide range of linkage and inference techniques, and depict the main performance trends. We consider two simulation scenarios, corresponding to the primary and secondary analysis settings.

4.1 Scenario 1: Primary analysis

4.1.1 Simulation design

We generate files ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A} and ğğ\mathbf{B} of sizes nA=600subscriptğ‘›ğ´600n_{A}=600 and nB=900subscriptğ‘›ğµ900n_{B}=900, respectively. The simulations are designed as a factorial experiment with six factors classified into five main categories:

  1. 1.

    Overlap: The overlap represents the proportion of true links. It is defined as the proportion of records from file ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A} that exist in file ğğ\mathbf{B}, as a fraction of the smaller file. We examine three levels of the overlap: 100% (complete overlap), 50% (medium overlap), and 20% (low overlap).

  2. 2.

    Blocking: We consider two blocking scenarios. In the first scenario, both files comprise 6 blocks. Consequently, there are 100 records per block in file ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}, and 150 records per block in file ğğ\mathbf{B}. In the second scenario, both files comprise 60 blocks, so that each block in file ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A} contains 10 records, and each block in file ğğ\mathbf{B} contains 15 records.

  3. 3.

    Linking variables: We examine the effect of the discriminatory power (DP) of the linking variables under two scenarios. In the high DP scenario, we simulate four linking variables that represent an individualâ€™s zip code stratum (with 30 categories), last name (with nA+nBâˆ’nAâ€‹Bsubscriptğ‘›ğ´subscriptğ‘›ğµsubscriptğ‘›ğ´ğµn_{A}+n_{B}-n_{AB} unique values), race (with 5 categories), and year of birth. In the low DP scenario, we simulate four variables to represent individualâ€™s gender (with 2 categories), last name (with nAsubscriptğ‘›ğ´n_{A} unique values), race (with 5 categories), and year of birth. In both cases, we generate the year of birth and race from the same distributions, but vary how the other linking variables are generated.

  4. 4.

    Variables for post-linkage analysis: For record pairs that are links, we generate ğ˜Asubscriptğ˜ğ´\mathbf{Y}_{A} and ğ—Bsubscriptğ—ğµ\mathbf{X}_{B} from a bivariate normal distribution

    (YAâ€‹lXBâ€‹l)â€‹âˆ¼iâ€‹iâ€‹dâ€‹N2â€‹((00),(42â€‹Ï2â€‹Ï1)).matrixsubscriptğ‘Œğ´ğ‘™subscriptğ‘‹ğµğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘‘similar-tosubscriptğ‘2matrix00matrix42ğœŒ2ğœŒ1\displaystyle\begin{pmatrix}Y_{Al}\\ X_{Bl}\end{pmatrix}\overset{iid}{\sim}N_{2}\left(\begin{pmatrix}0\\ 0\end{pmatrix},\begin{pmatrix}4&2\rho\\ 2\rho&1\end{pmatrix}\right). (15)

    Under this setup, a linear regression of ğ˜Asubscriptğ˜ğ´\mathbf{Y}_{A} on ğ—Bsubscriptğ—ğµ\mathbf{X}_{B} is of the form YAâ€‹l=Î²â€‹XBâ€‹l+Ïµlsubscriptğ‘Œğ´ğ‘™ğ›½subscriptğ‘‹ğµğ‘™subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™{Y}_{Al}=\beta X_{Bl}+\epsilon_{l}, where Î²=2â€‹Ïğ›½2ğœŒ\beta=2\rho, and Ïµlâ€‹âˆ¼iâ€‹iâ€‹dâ€‹Nâ€‹(0,4â€‹(1âˆ’Ï2))subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘‘similar-toğ‘041superscriptğœŒ2\epsilon_{l}\overset{iid}{\sim}N(0,4(1-\rho^{2})).
